explanation: Snell's law describes the relationship between the angles of incidence and refraction when light passes from one medium to another with different optical properties. The law states that the product of refractive index and sine of angle remains constant across the interface. This fundamental principle governs the behavior of light in lenses, prisms, optical fibers, and explains phenomena like total internal reflection and mirages.

definitions.definition: Refractive index of the first medium (incident medium).
Refractive index of the second medium (transmitted medium).
Angle of incidence (measured from the normal to the interface).
Angle of refraction (measured from the normal to the interface).
Speed of light in the medium.

assumptions: The interface between media is smooth and well-defined.
The media are homogeneous and isotropic.
Geometric optics applies (wavelength much smaller than relevant length scales).
The light beam is a plane wave with well-defined direction.
Fermat's principle applies: light takes the path of stationary optical path length.
The optical path length is the integral of refractive index along the path.
The interface is planar and the geometry can be described in 2D coordinates.
The refractive index is constant within each medium.

derivation.description: Define the optical path length as the integral of refractive index along the light path.

Apply the condition for stationary path: derivative with respect to the variable parameter equals zero.
Calculate the partial derivative of optical path length with respect to x-coordinate of interface point.
Rearrange the stationarity condition to separate terms from each medium.
Recognize that the ratio represents the sine of the incident angle.
Recognize that the ratio represents the sine of the refraction angle.
Substitute the trigonometric identities to obtain Snell's law.
Express the wave speed in terms of vacuum speed and refractive index.
Define refractive index as the ratio of vacuum speed to medium speed.
